title: The Work of God
teaser: Understanding the ultimate foundation of our security as believers and how God's will guarantees our eternal destiny
theme: The ultimate foundation of our security as believers — God's will is the unshakable foundation of our salvation

emphasis: I have come down from heaven not to do my will but to do the will of him who sent me
I shall lose none of all those he has given me, but raise them up at the last day
modules.passage: For I have come down from heaven not to do my will but to do the will of him who sent me. And this is the will of him who sent me, that I shall lose none of all those he has given me, but raise them up at the last day. For my Father's will is that everyone who looks to the Son and believes in him shall have eternal life, and I will raise them up at the last day.

fullPassage.text: When they found him on the other side of the lake, they asked him, 'Rabbi, when did you get here?' Jesus answered, 'Very truly I tell you, you are looking for me, not because you saw the signs I performed but because you ate the loaves and had your fill. Do not work for food that spoils, but for food that endures to eternal life, which the Son of Man will give you. For on him God the Father has placed his seal of approval.' Then they asked him, 'What must we do to do the works God requires?' Jesus answered, 'The work of God is this: to believe in the one he has sent.' So they asked him, 'What sign then will you give that we may see it and believe you? What will you do? Our ancestors ate the manna in the wilderness; as it is written: He gave them bread from heaven to eat.' Jesus said to them, 'Very truly I tell you, it is not Moses who has given you the bread from heaven, but it is my Father who gives you the true bread from heaven. For the bread of God is the bread that comes down from heaven and gives life to the world.' 'Sir,' they said, 'always give us this bread.' Then Jesus declared, 'I am the bread of life. Whoever comes to me will never go hungry, and whoever believes in me will never be thirsty. But as I told you, you have seen me and still you do not believe. All those the Father gives me will come to me, and whoever comes to me I will never drive away. For I have come down from heaven not to do my will but to do the will of him who sent me. And this is the will of him who sent me, that I shall lose none of all those he has given me, but raise them up at the last day. For my Father's will is that everyone who looks to the Son and believes in him shall have eternal life, and I will raise them up at the last day.'

modules.rootMeaning: The security of our salvation is rooted not in our will, but in God's powerful and unchanging thelema. Jesus came to carry out the Father's will, and that will has two parts: to lose none and to raise them up.
modules.usageNote: In John 6:38-40, thelema appears three times, emphasizing that the Father's will is the driving force behind Jesus's mission. The Father's will is the unshakable foundation of our eternal security.

modules.definition: will, desire, purpose — the driving force behind Jesus's mission and the foundation of our eternal security
modules.usage: In John 6:38-40, thelema describes the Father's sovereign purpose: that Jesus should lose none of those given to him and raise them up on the last day. Our security is rooted in God's unchanging will, not our fluctuating performance.

modules.body:
In verse 38, Jesus states his mission with perfect clarity: 'For I have come down from heaven not to do my will but to do the will of him who sent me.' Jesus's entire life and ministry were characterized by a perfect submission to the will of the Father. This is the foundation of our confidence. Our salvation is not dependent on a fallible human will, but on the perfect, unwavering obedience of the Son of God.

Jesus then defines the Father's will in two parts, creating a divine bracket around the life of the believer that guarantees their eternal security.

The first part is the promise of preservation (v. 39a): 'that I shall lose none of all those he has given me.' This is a promise of divine keeping. The word for 'lose' is apollymi, the same word used for the 'spoiling' food in verse 27. It means 'to destroy' or 'to let perish.' Jesus promises that he will not allow any of his true sheep to perish. This directly addresses the fear that we might lose our salvation. Our security is not based on our ability to persevere, but on Christ's power to preserve us.

The second part is the promise of resurrection (v. 39b): 'but raise them up at the last day.' This is the ultimate fulfillment of salvation. It is not just about being forgiven in this life, but about being given a new, glorified, resurrected body in the life to come. The phrase 'the last day' refers to the final consummation of history, when Christ returns and brings his kingdom in its fullness. This promise anchors our hope not just in a past event (the cross) or a present reality (our relationship with Christ), but in a future certainty (our resurrection).

In verse 40, Jesus restates the will of the Father from our perspective. The condition is that 'everyone who looks to the Son and believes in him' — where 'looks to' (theoreo) implies more than a casual glance; it is a steady, focused gaze, a contemplation that leads to belief. The consequence is 'shall have eternal life, and I will raise them up at the last day.' Eternal life is not just something we get when we die; it is a present possession. It is a quality of life, a participation in the life of God, that begins the moment we believe.
modules.keyInsight: Our eternal security is not based on the strength of our grip on God, but on the strength of his grip on us. His will is the unshakable foundation of our salvation — he will lose none and raise all on the last day.

modules.body:
Liam stood by the fire pit in the backyard, the warmth of the flames pushing back the late November chill. His father came and stood beside him, holding two mugs of hot cider.

'Your mother tells me you're a history teacher,' his father said, handing him a mug.

'That's right,' Liam replied, surprised. He had been a history teacher for ten years, but he wasn't sure his father had ever really taken an interest.

'I always thought that was... a waste of your potential,' his father admitted, his voice gruff. 'You were smart enough to be a lawyer, like your brother.'

Liam braced himself for the familiar lecture. But it didn't come.

'But watching you this weekend...' his father continued, staring into the fire. 'You seem... content. More content than Mark, with all his success. More content than me.'

He took a sip of his cider. 'This morning, I read that passage you showed me. The one about the bread of life. I kept reading. And I came to the part where Jesus talks about the will of the Father.'

He looked at Liam, his eyes searching. 'He says that it's God's will that he should lose none of those the Father has given him. That he will raise them up on the last day.'

'That's right,' Liam said softly.

'All my life,' his father said, his voice cracking slightly, 'I've been trying to build something that will last. A business, a legacy, a family. I've been trying to hold it all together, to make sure nothing gets lost. And I'm so tired. Because things always get lost. People leave. Businesses fail. Health fades. You can't hold on to anything.'

He looked at his hands, calloused from years of work. 'But this... this says that God is the one holding on. That if you belong to him, he will not lose you. That he will raise you up. That's a security you can't build, can't earn, can't buy.'

Liam felt a lump in his throat. This was the conversation he had longed to have with his father his entire life.

'No, Dad,' he said. 'You can't. It's a gift.'

'A gift,' his father repeated, a sense of wonder in his voice. 'All this time, I've been trying to earn my place at the table, and he's just... giving it away.'

They stood in silence for a long time, watching the flames dance. The gap between them, a chasm of unspoken expectations and disappointments, seemed to be closing. They were just two men, a father and a son, standing before the fire, contemplating the profound, life-altering truth of a grace that holds on and never lets go.

Liam realized that this was the true Thanksgiving. It wasn't about the food, or the family, or the performance. It was about this. It was about standing in the warmth of God's unwavering will, and knowing, with a deep and settled confidence, that you are secure. Not because of what you have done, but because of who is holding you.
modules.connectionToTheme: Liam's father, who spent his life trying to build lasting security through business and legacy, discovers the one security that cannot be earned or lost: God's sovereign will to preserve his people and raise them up on the last day.

modules.body: The concept of God as a shepherd who keeps his flock and does not lose any of them is a powerful theme in the Old Testament. Ezekiel 34:11-12, 16 says, 'For this is what the Sovereign Lord says: I myself will search for my sheep and look after them. As a shepherd looks after his scattered flock when he is with them, so will I look after my sheep. I will rescue them from all the places where they were scattered... I will search for the lost and bring back the strays. I will bind up the injured and strengthen the weak.' Jesus, in John 10, will explicitly identify himself as the Good Shepherd who fulfills this promise. Here in John 6, he is making the same claim: he is the one who will seek, save, and secure the flock of God, losing none.
modules.historicalContext: The word apollymi ('to lose,' 'to destroy') in verse 39 is the same word used in verse 27 for food that 'spoils.' This verbal connection is intentional. The crowd is pursuing bread that apollymi — perishes. But Jesus promises that those given to him will never apollymi — perish. The contrast is stark: everything the world offers eventually perishes, but those who belong to Christ are eternally preserved.
modules.fascinatingFact: The phrase 'raise them up at the last day' appears four times in John 6 (verses 39, 40, 44, and 54). This repetition is not accidental. It is Jesus's emphatic, fourfold promise that the story does not end at death. The resurrection is not an afterthought; it is the climax of God's redemptive plan.

modules.heading: The Shepherd Who Loses None

modules.ancientTruth: Jesus declared that his entire mission was to carry out the Father's will: to lose none of those given to him and to raise them up on the last day. The foundation of the believer's security is not their own faithfulness, but God's unchanging purpose.
modules.modernApplication: We live in a world of insecurity — job loss, health crises, broken relationships, economic uncertainty. We try to build security through our own efforts, but it always crumbles. God offers an unshakable security rooted in his sovereign will. Our eternal destiny depends not on our ability to hold on, but on his commitment to never let go.
modules.connectionPoint: The same weariness that Liam's father felt — the exhaustion of trying to hold everything together — is the universal human condition. Jesus offers rest from that striving by shifting the foundation of our security from our performance to God's will.
modules.newTestamentEcho: Paul celebrates this security in Romans 8:38-39: 'For I am convinced that neither death nor life, neither angels nor demons, neither the present nor the future, nor any powers, neither height nor depth, nor anything else in all creation, will be able to separate us from the love of God that is in Christ Jesus our Lord.'

modules.prompt: Where am I currently placing my sense of security? In my own performance, my circumstances, or in the unchanging will of God?
additionalQuestions: How does the truth that your salvation is secured by God's will, not your own, change the way you view your struggles, doubts, and failures?
Read verse 40 again slowly. Personalize it by putting your own name in it. How does this affect you?

modules.prayerText: Father, thank you for your sovereign will. Thank you that my salvation is not dependent on my ability to hold on, but on your promise to never let me go. Help me to live in the confidence and freedom of that truth. Amen.

modules.commitment: Stop trying to secure your own salvation. Today, consciously release your grip on the things you are trusting for security and thank God that your eternal destiny is held securely in his will.
leavingAtCross: The fear that I might lose my salvation through failure or weakness
The exhausting effort to hold everything together by my own strength
The insecurity of placing my hope in things that perish
receivingFromCross: The promise of preservation — Christ will lose none of those given to him
The promise of resurrection — he will raise us up on the last day
The unshakable security of God's sovereign, unchanging will
modules.content: Stop trying to secure your own salvation. Today, consciously release your grip on the things you are trusting for security and thank God that your eternal destiny is held securely in his will.

forReflection: How does the truth that your salvation is secured by God's will, not your own, change the way you view your struggles, doubts, and failures?
What is the most comforting aspect of Jesus's promise in these verses — the promise of preservation ('lose none') or the promise of resurrection ('raise them up')? Why?
forAccountabilityPartners: Share one area where you are trying to build your own security instead of resting in God's will
Discuss: How does understanding God's will as the foundation of our security change the way we face uncertainty?
Read verse 40 aloud and personalize it with each other's names. What does this mean for your daily life?

modules.name: Jesus, the Obedient Son
modules.title: The One Who Came to Do the Father's Will
modules.description: In these verses, Jesus reveals the ultimate purpose of his mission: perfect obedience to the Father's will. He came down from heaven not to pursue his own agenda, but to carry out a divine rescue mission — to lose none of those the Father has given him and to raise them up on the last day. His obedience is the foundation of our security.
modules.keyQuote: For I have come down from heaven not to do my will but to do the will of him who sent me.
modules.lessonForUs: Our eternal security rests not on our own performance or perseverance, but on the perfect obedience of the Son and the sovereign will of the Father. The two promises — preservation and resurrection — create an unbreakable divine bracket around every believer's life.
modules.heading: The One Who Came to Do the Father's Will
